children.text:
Vera, what do you
think is the significance of the
youth being here at this conference?

Um, I think it's
significant that the youth is here
today to recognize and be able to

have a discourse with, um, older
writers that are here and people
who are out in the community.

A lot of people that are here
are teachers as well as writers.

And I think it's good to have some
type of discourse with the youth that
are out here doing something today
besides it being in kind of like an

academic setting where it's like peer
and teacher positions or something like
that so they can like Just have an easy
flowing like conversation or whatever.

Has there been
a lot of dialogue between the
elder literary folk and the young
aspiring writers in your opinion?

Um, I
actually don't think so.

No, I think it's, everything has been
actually pretty much respectful and I
was hoping to catch Jabari Asim today,
actually, because he was going to talk

a little bit about hip hop and I wanted
to hear what he had to say about that,
the younger people and older people also.

Which is something we were
discussing last night.

We just had a kind of like free for
all back at the hotel where young
writers and older writers actually

were reading their work and some
people just came out of curiosity.

And that was a lot of people's main
concern as to what was going on in terms
of like discourse between and um, critical

critiquing of these older writers and
what they had done and what we should be
doing now and whatever, things like that.

Yeah, I thought that
was a very special moment myself, uh,
primarily because it was the first visible
moment in which you did see, uh, these

young writers who have been reading,
uh, Gwendolyn Brooks, you know, highly
anthologized woman, uh, who have heard
the, the, Older poets who have been on

the periphery like Kalamu, Yassalam, and
Eskeetore, uh, to, uh, finally engage
them on their work and their times,
you know, the black arts movement.

And I think on some level, um,
anticipating the need to, uh,
define for them, uh, how poetry

is going to be received, uh,
aesthetically in the community,
um, functionally in the community.
And, in their own lives, you know.

I think it was also good, um,
that they saw these people who are
actually living writers as opposed
to just being like on a page as well.

And seeing
them be accessible to them, I
thought that was a good thing.
Right.

Well, Dolores, so
happy you could be here today.

I'm glad
to see you too, Judith.

Tell me about the
excitement that you're feeling.

about this wonderful conference in
relation to what you yourself have,
um, contributed to the world of poetry.

Well, I think it's
sort of a milestone of, uh, in terms of
literature in this country because if

you really think about it, uh, You'll
never get together these many poets,
these prominent poets, these kinds of

poets, these poets who are involved in
this kind of thinking and movement again
for probably another 30 or 40 years.
I mean, as we have it today.

Uh, Sam Allen and I
were talking about that.

Saying what a celebration, it's really
a celebration when it comes down to it.

And, uh, it's a privilege to be
here with, with so many, uh, minds.

With so many people who feel talking
about poetry is normal and natural.

Because I know in my environment,
no matter, even in some places
in the academia, how do you feel?

Some places in the academia,
some people are very, very
tender when it comes to poetry.

Um, so it's nice to be able to talk
with people and be with people.

And I think it's making a
contribution, not only to this
community, but as it goes, probably,
to the whole world of poetry.
How do you feel about it?

Well, you know, what's
exciting to me is that, um, as I
listen to the reading of the poetry,
and I talk to people like yourself,

and you know, I've interacted with
Nikki Giovanni on several occasions,
and of course with Sonia Sanchez.

What's, what's so exciting about
today is that, um, I'm seeing
poetry, in a way, become alive.

And, um, and it's sort of embodying,
for me, Um, uh, everything that African
Americans have been in the past.

the present and what they
will be in the future.

So I think that's, you know, what's sort
of, uh, exciting to me about being here.

And, you know, and as, uh, as I look
at you and, and I've read a couple
of the things that you've written
and I think what, what has sort of

been impressive to me about having
someone like you to dialogue with
is how you use poetry to teach.

And I was wondering if you could
speak to that for a few minutes.

Yeah, I, um, I know
you're not talking about didacticism.
I know you're not saying that.

What I try to do is to, is
to define a situation or
people involved in situations.

And through that, to get the reader
to look At himself or herself.

In other words, and I'm very involved
in the spiritual nature of man.
And how our spirits overcome in the end.
How they survive and overcome in the end.
Um, that may be a teaching.

If somebody reads a poem and says, well,
well, I'll give you a good example.

There was a woman who read from the
Woman of Plums, Peggy and Killing.

And that's a poem about one of the
slave women who kills her children
rather than have them become slaves.

Um, this, this is the, you probably know
it, the, the narrative of Margaret Garner.
And it was based on that narrative.

And I did a reading in Boston, and after
I finished, this woman came up to me
in tears, and she was a white woman.
And I said, you must be a mother.
She said, yes.

So you see, if poetry can move, uh, people
into a, uh, a finer, a truer recognition
of who they are and themselves, and get

them to renew themselves in some way, or
spiritually renew themselves in some way.
That I, I, I think it works.
And I don't set out to do that.

Sometimes the poem takes me
there and I just follow it.
You must have that experience.
I mean, it simply takes you there.

And if, and if you don't
follow it, you are rejecting.
the muse or whatever you want to call it.
You're rejecting your own creativity.
But the poem takes me there.

That's why I get a little worried
sometimes when people start
defining poetry as political poetry
or this poetry or that poetry.
One goes where the poem takes one.

And I think even when we talk of Gwendolyn
Brooks, who I think is probably the
finest, the greatest genius of us all,

uh, her poems simply take you into
yourself and bring you out again whole.

And it seems to me that's
what I like to see poems do.

Now, whatever Definition,
people want to give that.
If it makes them comfortable, fine.
But I don't think I'm in any of them.

In fact, Paul Breiman, when he
first printed me, wrote on the
back of my, my little chapbook,
you can't put her in the category.

And I realized that's
going to get me in trouble.

I said, since he wrote that, I said,
it's going to get me in trouble.
But there it is.
How, how do you see that?
Do you, do you, do you see poetry?

People talked this morning
about poetry as political.
Poetry as a political force.
Well, what do you think of that?

Well, you know, my
response is, is, is pretty simple.

It can be a powerful political
force, but I think that you have
to allow it to take you wherever.
Yes.

And as long as you understand that poetry,
of course, is an art form, and that it
does transcend politics, as it were.

But if it takes you there and allows
you to have a deeper understanding,
political situation at that particular
time, then it's done its job.
It has worked for you in that context.

Um, what struck me today, and I
wondered what you thought about this,
um, was of course, the, uh, speakers,

um, uh, allusion to, of course, Ralph
Ellison's work, The Invisible Man.

And I've never heard anyone, um, In a
sense, extrapolate from his invisible,
from Ellison's Invisible Man, what he did.

And I thought that, uh, when I found
out that I was going to have this chat
with you, I thought I'd love to get

your opinion on his, his, uh, analysis
of what the Invisible Man has done
as it speaks to the black community.
Or as he spoke to the black community.

Let me move
into my experience and try to
explain that through my experience.

When I read Ralph Ellison's The
Invisible Man, I was overwhelmed
by the art of the book.

Um, some of it leaning on, um,
on, on poetry in many aspects.

But I was overwhelmed
by the art of the book.

Until I went back, until I had
an experience myself, in which I
discovered what being made invisible is.

And that is through working in a
largely white institution, where if
you become something other than what

you are supposed to become, there
is a way of making you invisible.

As a woman in a male world, There is a way
of making you invisible, and it doesn't
always come from the white community.

It can come from the black
community, which Ellison tells us
about in a few of those chapters.
Yes, it does.

Uh, I, I think what
Ellison did for me was to give me a
whole new experience of what this term

invisible means and how it relates to me,
not only, not only as a woman, an African
American movement, but as a human being.

Because no human being
should be made invisible.
Absolutely.

And I think he makes
that statement very, very powerfully.

Because remember, in The Visible
Man, he, he gets, he gets
blown away by his own people.
That's right.
Half the time.
So, I, I, I don't know whether,

What message, can
you then translate that into the
message for, to, for the, for
the contemporary black community?
What is it that we need to do?

It's obvious that, you know, we meet
in some way the criteria for middle
classness, whatever that means.

How can we use what Ralph Ellison tells
us in The Invisible Man and the poetry
of some of the people who are here

today, as well as your own writing,
to connect with the black community?
How can we do that?

I think, first
of all, we, and I sound like I know
what I'm talking about, don't I?

I, I got a lot, a lot of living
to do before I could even back
up this answer I'm gonna give.

But I, I think, first of all, we have
to learn how to empower ourselves.

And we empower ourselves by knowing our
history, by, uh, networking, by bonding.

Uh, there is, there is so much,
so much Out here, that allows
us to separate from each other.

For, for, for reasons,
for one reason or another.

And to allow what energies there are
out here that wants, that want to
see us separated and disinherited
and invisible and unempowered.

These, these energies come in
and do it very beautifully.

Take, uh, Toni Morrison's
getting the Nobel.
Right.

And the, the backlash that came from
her contemporary black, uh, uh, writers.

Why do
you suppose that was?

But, I think
it's, my mother used to have a
phrase for that, if I dare say it.
Yeah, please tell us.

My mother
used to say crabs in a barrel.

She used to say that we have not
gotten away from the plantation,
because in the plantation the
master used to get the crabs.

People, some people to spy on other
people and let them know what's going
on and they, they were able to keep

their, uh, faith or keep themselves
together was a desperate, desperate move.

Um, to some degree, we, some of us may
still be there because we are being,
uh, usurped or by the white community
that does not want to see us empowered.

After all, if a black person
receives a Nobel, that's a,
that's empowerment, period.
That's empowerment.

I mean, probably the greatest
you can get in literature.

And, and, if you can find people
out here who are going to give
a certain backlash, and And sort
of make that person invisible.

Think of that, making a Nobel
Prize winner invisible and using
black people in order to do it.

And I, I don't know why we don't see
through that except that our need
to be noticed, our need to become
visible is so great that we will buy

into that in order to make another
Part of ourselves, and ourselves
would be another person, invisible.

I think we've got a lot to learn, to
answer your question, that we have to
go into the schools, teach the children,

make the children proud of their heritage,
stop them from, you know, Toni Morrison
said that we all wanted to forget slavery.

She said, um, blacks wanted to forget it
because they wanted to put it behind us.

Uh, whites wanted to forget
it because of the grief.

And she made the statement,
I think, in Time Magazine.

She says she thinks we
all have national amnesia.
Well, it's time we're done with that.

And we begin to do what the Jews
have done with the Holocaust.

And let the world know that
we are proud of what we did.

We, we rose up from one of the
first holocausts in this country.
And, and became a very strong Powerful.
Yes, powerful people.

And I think we have to
teach our children that.
Teach our children to be proud of that.
Teach them how to network.
You know, we say brother and sister.
But sometimes we don't really mean that.

And, and, and try to get our, our,
our kids in a positive view of
themselves, to like themselves, to

love themselves, through their history,
and through other forms of education.

And, and of
course through, through poetry.
Exactly.
Through poetry they can do that.

I think you've heard, I don't know,
have you heard that, uh, Judith,
that there are many young people
who don't know of, of James Baldwin?
I live that every day.
I live it every day.
Yeah.

Historically black institution and I'm
amazed at the number of young black men
and women who have not had any exposure
To black art as it were in any form.
Absolutely.

And that's why
of course this Celebration you
and I are experiencing today.
It's so important.

It's so important In fact that I was
going to ask you where you were on
how one could infuse This whole black
literature experience into the existing

curricula in both the public or in the
private, public and parochial schools that
would allow not only black young men and

women to become empowered through their
literature, but would allow our white
brothers and sisters and Asian brothers

and sisters and Latino brothers and
sisters to understand the African American
experience through their literature.
Poetry.
Yes.

And I, and I wondered with your experience
at Philip Exeter, which is one of the
finest, uh, uh, uh, private schools in
the country, Uh, did, were you able to use

poetry as a vehicle through which and by
which your young students could then, in
a sense, experience, um, black culture?

A small
example, Gwendolyn Brooks poem
of the life of Lincoln West.

That is an extraordinary poem about
this young kid who is, and when
Gwen reads it, she said he was ugly.
She really uses that word, ugly.

She reads this wonderful poem
about this young kid who is ugly
and, uh, whom everybody rejects.
And, and she goes through it all.

The mother, the teacher,
everybody rejects him.

The teacher takes her to a,
takes him to a, I mean the mother
takes him to a film one day.
And this white man across the street.

The way he says to the, aloud
to his girlfriend, Look!
That's a real one.
A real one.
Look at the nappy hair.
That's an original.

And at the end of the poem, the
young boy says, works out proudly,
he takes that insult and, and
turns it into a celebration.
And he says, I am an original.

We read that at Exeter and I said, you
know, we talked about what is an original.

We talk about all the original
clothes they buy, all the
money these clothes talk.
What does original mean?

Because basically, I'm ta you're talking
to a bunch of kids, even though they
are well off and whatnot, are having

the same kind of traumatic problems
that most kids out here are having.

But here they see through a black
child, and this black child's
willingness to celebrate himself,
how they can celebrate themselves.

That because that they're
having almost the same problems.

And when that begins to connect,
they It connects beautifully,
because they say, Ah, a black kid
is teaching me this, you know.

And, and, or a black
woman is teaching me this.

Believe me, Gwen became very
popular after that poem was taken,
uh, uh, taught so many times.
She had been popular.

But what I'm saying is that you
can use, as your question implies,
does that make sense to you?
Yes, it does.
Very much so.

And I just want to say it was
so fun chatting with you today.

And maybe you and I can continue
this conversation another time.
I hope so, Julie.
We have to do that.
Yes.

Pinky, I'd like to
ask you a variant on the question
you ask in freshman composition

classes, and that is, when and why
and how did you start writing poetry?

How
did I start writing poetry?

Uh, I started writing poetry, I really
came to poetry late in life because
I was writing fiction although I
hadn't gotten anything published.

But I had thought I wanted
to be a fiction writer.

And then I discovered the, uh,
person to whom this conference is
dedicated, uh, Gwendolyn Brooks.

Uh, uh, I read her first book
of poetry, Speed and Bronx, many
years after it was published.
And I said, gee, that's what I want to do.

And I started writing poetry
and I found out my temperament
was more suited to that.

And I've been really dedicating all of
my time now to writing poetry rather
than, uh, venturing off into other media.
Okay.

But she
was my, she was really my
inspiration, Gwendolyn Brooks.
Wonderful woman.
I love her.

And she's from
my city too, so I do too.
Share that love.

But you say your
temperament was more suited.
Can you push that for me a little bit?
All right.

I suppose I was thinking, not only
because I can deal with a poem,
It's more, it's more confined.
It's more condensed.

Uh, I can write it while I'm
sitting in the automobile.

Or I can write it as I have done,
uh, between classes in my office.

At that time I was teaching
at Southern University.

And I, I think as a fiction writer
you'd have to be much more disciplined
in doing something every day.

If you're gonna, if you're, if
you're Writing a novel, for example.

And I just never, I taught
for many, many years.
And my students were my priority.

And I just didn't have time to sit
down and say I'm going to devote four
hours or eight hours a day to that.

But also because I, uh, got a kind
of an emotional, or a release,
and a feel for writing a poem.

I always felt good when
a poem was finished.
You see?

And so I suppose that's what I mean when I
say my temperament was more suited to it.

Uh, it seemed to, to, uh, satisfy
some inner thing inside of me
that I, uh, evidently wanted
to let out, wanted to surface.

Okay, that, that
brings to mind two questions for me.
Um, the first has to do with form.

You said that the poetry is
really brief and it allowed you
to work in short time spans.
So, did you, do you do a lot of revising?

Or, um, in part two of that,
after revision, is that the form
of your poetry seems to be the
short, clipped kinds of lines.

Uh, I, uh,
don't do a lot of revising.

Depends on what you mean a lot,
because it's a relative term.
Uh, but I do do some revising.

And whenever I do revise, it's
always a matter of cutting
down, sharpening the image.
You see, I'm an imagist.
Okay.

I'm very much concerned with
the metaphor and the way
something is said, the language.

Uh, as well as the content
of what you have to say.

And, uh, when I'm first writing,
Of course, I'm just putting down
everything that comes into my head as
fast as I can before I lose the idea.
Then I begin to cut down.
I begin to look at the imagery.
I begin to look at the words.
Uh, the concise meaning of words.
Uh, is the image a cliché?
Uh, is it, uh, does it have originality?
What kind of power does it have?

So when I revise, I'm always
looking for, I'm revising in
terms of technique and style.
I've already said what I want to say.

You know, the thought is there, but I'm
concerned with then the use of language.

Alright, and the thought
seems to be, I, I was looking at
some of your poems before I came to
the conference and um, there's a new

volume out that our library happened
to have and I cannot call the name of
it, right at the, Girl at the Window.
Girl at it is, Girl at the Window.

And I was, as I was reading those poems, I
noticed that a lot of them deal with love
and, Pain and some vivid recollections
intermixed with ruined lives.
Pain intermixed with ruined lives.
Where is that coming from?

You know, uh,
some of the poems in that book go back
quite a long way because some of them

are poems that had been previously
published and, uh, of course some of
them, uh, a number of them are new poems.

So it's a kind of a documentary of my
life and my emotional life, my psychic
life all, uh, through, over several years.
Uh, I don't feel pain anymore.
I'm a happy person.

But, you know, we, we, uh, we do have
to struggle, uh, to know ourselves and
what our identity, uh, happens to be.

And I suppose that through those
years I was, I was looking for my,
who, who really is Pinkie Lane.
And so this, uh, a lot of it was pain.
You see, a lot of it was pain.

Because I had a, really had a,
I had a struggling childhood.

My father was an alcoholic and,
uh, it was a dysfunctional family.

I was dealing with this years
after he had died, you see.

I came to terms with it, but I think
my poetry helped me to do that.

Because a section in the
poem, To Your Father, is the one that
really I was thinking about the most.
Yes.

When you talk
about divorcing your father.
Yes.

And then
there's a poem about an uncle.
Oh, yes, yes.

And both of those were,
uh, yes, very painful poems to do.

Well, I
see a lot of my poems too come,
uh, are rooted in my family.

You know, I'm a, I'm a really
a family oriented person.
I have some poems to my son.
Uh, family's important to me.

So I, um, I use a lot of my imagery
and a lot of my content comes from,
um, my, that kind of association.

But then, you know, I eclectic,
I write about everything
Oh, good.
Yeah.
Good.
I had another couple of questions.

And one of those has to do with the
context of this particular conference.

The session this morning dealt
with finding the vernacular
matrix in African American poetry.

And since you say you're eclectic,
which is a good lead in, how do you see
yourself fitting in with that notion of

a vernacular tradition, or a vernacular
mainstream, or vernacular matrix,
rather, between folk and popular poetry?
Um,

I guess the only way that my portrait
would fit in with the folk tradition would
be perhaps my choice of subject matter.

Because I, uh, I'm very much
rooted, you know, in my background
and rooted in the folk tradition.

But I think in terms of the technique,
uh, I'm a, uh, It's, it's, uh, it's,
my academic background comes into play.
Uh, I, I, um, I'm an educated person.

And so I write in terms of the
language which it has, I have
grown, grown into, you see.

And this is why I suppose the
metaphor is so important to me.

I did a whole doctoral
dissertation on the metaphor.
A 300 page, just on the poetic metaphor.

So when I say, uh, the, the metaphorical
image, I'm really talking from the
background of, uh, Uh, an intensive
amount of study of that art form.
So I'm a mixture of both, you see.

There is the folk there, but there's
also the, I guess you'd call it
the, sophisticated, uh, uh, uh,
tradition that's coming in there.
I'm a mixture of that.

And I make no apologies
for that, you know.
I, I, this is what I am.

Well, we certainly
aren't asking you to apologize.
We certainly are not.

So you see your work taking place
more, less as performance poetry,
and more as poetry to be read in
university or the classroom setting?

Well, when you
say performance, as if so happens,
that even right now, there is a
violinist, a composer in Baton Rouge.

He used to be the first violinist
for Baton Rouge Symphony.

So he's strictly in the
classical tradition.

Contemporary classical tradition, who
has sent three of my poems to, to music.

And they are going to be performed
on October the 19th and the 22nd,
in Baton Rouge, in a week that
we call Louisiana Heritage Week.

And he has done this before, uh, about
eight years, about five years ago.
He, uh, selected three poems.
Those are three love poems.

These poems are all, uh, these
three poems are, um, um, uh,
He selected the theme of music.
One's called Lyric I'm Looking at Music.

One's called Two Singers of
Song, and one's called Violins.

But what he does, you
see, he has an orchestra.
He works with graduate students.

So he really has, he's written
the parts for the various
instruments, string instruments.

And I will just read
portions of the poems.
He will give me a nod.
So in that sense, it's performance.
We're gonna perform those three poems.

So I guess you could say I fit into,
I mean, you can perform Anything,
if you apply the right techniques.

Again, just
a different venue, too.
Yes, that's right.
Okay.
How do you see your work?

in relationship to the so called canon in
American poetry and also in relationship
to the canon in Black American or African

American poetry, particularly in light
of the Black Arts Movement of the 1960s.
Yes.

You know, I was telling someone this, that
we've been seeing now this morning, um, I

mentioned to the person sitting next
to me who happened to be Sybil Kine,
I said, you know, I remember once

when we had, we used to have a Black
Poetry Festival at Southern every year.
Was that the Melvin Dixon?
Melvin Butler.

Porphyry Festival, and then he died
after two years, and I took over
the directorship for seven years,
and we changed it to his name.

But I remember one of the persons who
came to our session was Dudley Randall.

At that time there was a lot of
rhetoric about what is black poetry?
What is black poetry?

And, uh, I asked Dudley, you know, I
wasn't playing the devil's advocate,
I wanted to get his point of view.
He was giving a talk that time.

I says, uh, Dudley, I says, what
is your definition of black poetry?

He says, oh, he says, my definition
of black poetry is any poetry
that's written by a black person.
Now you see, that was a good answer.

It means that he was not
being prescriptive, that you
must write a certain way.

You know, I'm still writing from my
perspective, and I'm, and ethically,
you know, I'm writing from the
African American perspective, you see.

What about your work vis a
vis the American, the broader American?
Oh.

Now, uh, I think in, in terms
of the broader America, I,
possibly my emphasis on technique.

You see, uh, the persons who have
given me a lot of support, uh, in
responding to my work have not just
been, um, African Americans, you see.

So that tells me that I must be
saying something that reaches
a broader spectrum to somebody.

Um, I, uh, uh, the fact that
I do emphasize technique.

The metaphor, which comes out of
a very long tradition, you see.

Fits me into, I think, the larger
context, not just of American
poetry, but of world poetry.
Mm
hmm.

Well, the answer
to the question is, I've tried to
put together two different forms.

There is, there's a kind of phrasing that
the great musicians, see I grew up with
Lester Young, who would go to the Savoy
Ballroom and he would play to the dancers.

He would get ideas from watching
people dance, and especially on Kitchen
Mechanic's Night, which was Thursday

night, when it cost a dollar to get in,
and he'd watch these dancers and then
he would come up with this phrasing.

So people wanted, where the phrasing
comes from, well every musician,
uh, every session is a new day.

They don't sound like the solos on the
records because that was just one time.
These people are improvising all the time.

And when you got geniuses out there,
uh, I said to myself, that's the source.

Now, how to make the bridge from that
musical um, linkage to a literary
one was always the issue for me.

Now, you could live under the security

and Gwendolyn had already done that They'd

There's no point imitating them You

They were already conversant in it.
But they were adding to it.
In a kind of theory of adaptation.

And then they would bring

Often times it came from Afro

Well they weren't trying to.

And the whole weight of one's life
